(['Python-Markdown'], ['This is a Python implementation of John Gruber’s
', '.
It is almost completely compliant with the reference implementation,
though there are a few very minor ', '. See John’s
', '
for the syntax rules.', 'To get started, see the ', ', the ', ', and the ', '.', 'The Python-Markdown project is developed with the following goals in mind:', 'Maintain a Python library (with an optional CLI wrapper) suited to use in web
  server environments (never raise an exception, never write to stdout, etc.) as
  an implementation of the markdown parser that follows the
  ', ' and the
  behavior of the original (markdown.pl) implementation as reasonably as
  possible (see ', ' for a few exceptions).', 'Provide an ', ' which makes it possible
  to change and/or extend the behavior of the parser.', 'In addition to the basic markdown syntax, Python-Markdown supports the following
features:', 'Python-Markdown will accept ', ' in any language
supported by Unicode including bi-directional text. In fact the test suite
includes documents written in Russian and Arabic.', 'Various ', ' are provided (including
', ') to change and/or extend the base syntax.
Additionally, a public ', ' is available
to write your own extensions.', 'Python-Markdown can output documents with either HTML or XHTML style tags.
See the ', ' for details.', 'In addition to being a Python Library, a
', ' is available for your convenience.', 'While Python-Markdown strives to fully implement markdown as described in the
', ', the rules
can be interpreted in different ways and different implementations
occasionally vary in their behavior (see the
', '
for some examples). Known and intentional differences found in Python-Markdown
are summarized below:', 'Python-Markdown defaults to ignoring middle-word emphasis (and strong
emphasis). In other words, ', ' will not become
', '. This can be switched off if desired. See
the ', ' for details.', 'The ', '
clearly state that when a list item consists of multiple paragraphs, “each
subsequent paragraph in a list item ', ' be indented by either 4 spaces
or one tab” (emphasis added). However, many implementations do not enforce
this rule and allow less than 4 spaces of indentation. The implementers of
Python-Markdown consider it a bug to not enforce this rule.', 'This applies to any block level elements nested in a list, including
paragraphs, sub-lists, blockquotes, code blocks, etc. They ', ' always
be indented by at least four spaces (or one tab) for each level of nesting.', 'In the event that one would prefer different behavior,
', ' can be set to whatever length is
desired. Be warned however, as this will affect indentation for all aspects
of the syntax (including root level code blocks). Alternatively, a 
', ' may offer a solution that meets your needs.', 'While the syntax rules are not clear on this, many implementations (including
the original) do not end one list and start a second list when the list marker
(asterisks, pluses, hyphens, and numbers) changes. For consistency,
Python-Markdown maintains the same behavior with no plans to change in the
foreseeable future. That said, the ', '
is available to provide a less surprising behavior.', 'You may report bugs, ask for help, and discuss various other issues on the ', '.', '
                ', '
            ', '
                    ', '
                ', '
                ', '
            ', '
                ', ' |
            ', '
                ', ' »
            ', '
